item.title: Classification of apparels from Fashion MNIST dataset using Keras
item.dc:creator: jsinghvi@blogger
item.description: In this post, we are going to talk about the Fashion MNIST dataset. It basically comprises of 55,000 Training Images and 10,000 Testing Images. Each one of them is a 28*28 grayscale image. Just like […]
item.content:encoded:
In this post, we are going to talk about the Fashion MNIST dataset. It basically comprises of 55,000 Training Images and 10,000 Testing Images. Each one of them is a 28*28 grayscale image. Just like the MNIST digits dataset, there are a total of 10 classes that the images can be classified into.

Let’s first start off with importing the necessary modules.

View the code on Gist.

Next, we’ll read the images and their labels in our script. Also, while we’re at it, let’s check their dimensions as well.

View the code on Gist.

To get an idea of how the image looks like, we could use the matplotlib’s imshow() function.

View the code on Gist.

Finally, let’s do some reshaping of the data so that it can be passed on to our neural network.

View the code on Gist.

Here comes the most important part! It’s time we define our Neural Network architecture using the Keras API.

View the code on Gist.

After we’re done defining the model, let’s feed it with the data that we have prepared. For starters, let’s keep the number of epochs to a small amount. You can always increase it, but beware of the overfitting demon.

View the code on Gist.

Time to put it to test? Hell yeah!

View the code on Gist.

Fhew! That was some pretty code for something so scary!

item.title: Simple Linear Regression using Python
item.dc:creator: jsinghvi@blogger
item.description: Whenever one sets off to study about Machine Learning, the first thing they inadvertently come across is Linear Regression. It is arguably the simplest ML model. Let’s take a quick look at it with it’s […]
item.content:encoded:
Whenever one sets off to study about Machine Learning, the first thing they inadvertently come across is Linear Regression. It is arguably the simplest ML model. Let’s take a quick look at it with it’s implementation using Python.

What is Linear Regression?

To put it in simple terms, Linear Regression is a statistical model that identifies the linear relationship between two or more variables – where one of them is the Dependent Variable and the other one(s) being Independent Variable(s). What this basically means is that when one increases, the other increases and vice versa.

We will be using Jupyter Notebook to run our code. The first thing we’ll be doing is to import the pandas module and read the datasets. I have stored my training and testing data in ‘linear.csv’ and ‘test.csv’ respectively.

View the code on Gist.

To see the shape of the training data, you can use train_data.shape , but if you wish to see some portion of the dataset, use .head attribute :

 

View the code on Gist.

Next, we’ll find the the mean values of the x and y attributes using the built-in mean() function. Also, we’ll be creating 2 new variables for further use.

View the code on Gist.

After this, we will calculate the initial value of m. The way this is done is by finding the standard deviation in the values of x and y. Also, the initial value of c is also found out.

View the code on Gist.

The last step is to Visualize the data using matplotlib module to plot the regression line.

View the code on Gist.

That’s it! That is just how Simple Linear Regression was.

PS : More posts coming soon!

item.title: Cry of the Sky
item.dc:creator: jsinghvi@blogger
item.description: As I sit inside the warmth of my room, the raindrops on the window catch my attention. The storm has finally settled down after an hour of downpour, but my heart hasn’t. Maybe it’s just […]
item.content:encoded:
As I sit inside the warmth of my room, the raindrops on the window catch my attention. The storm has finally settled down after an hour of downpour, but my heart hasn’t. Maybe it’s just my imagination, but over the past few months, every time that I witnessed a rainfall, it felt like it was calling out to me. While everyone heard the thunder’s mighty roar, I heard an outcry. Like, it was trying to tell us the pain that we have caused it. How, even after the ruthless way we treat it – the pollution, the overpopulation, the wastage, fuel hunting to name a few – it still bears us with such kindness.Â  We’ve hurt our planet far too much to even have the right to call it ‘Mother Earth’.

Every day, every minute, we tread a path there’s no turning back from. And the most pitiful thing is that we’d rather turn a blind eye than do something about it. Now you might say “You’re wrong! Look there’s Tesla making electric cars, Denmark using renewable energy, people planting tress, yada yada..”, but ask yourself this – Is this enough to make up for the sins we’ve committed? for all the recklessness we evince everyday?

Our fate hangs by a thread, but we insist on staying ignorant. The future seems unclear, and honestly, it feels like soon we’re gonna turn from Masters to Scavengers.. Any hope for our Salvation? Maybe not. Or is there?

item.title: How My Obsession with 30 Day Challenges Transformed My Life
item.dc:creator: jsinghvi@blogger
item.description: See that kid? Thatâ€™s who I have always been. The scared little guy who always overthinks about everything thrown at him, wondering if life is ever gonna get better. Last November, I came across an […]
item.content:encoded:
See that kid? Thatâ€™s who I have always been. The scared little guy who always overthinks about everything thrown at him, wondering if life is ever gonna get better.

Last November, I came across an interesting answer on Quora by John Michael Domingo where he mentioned the 30 Day Challenge routine. I was immediately intrigued.

Next thing I knew, I had embarked on a journey I had no idea would be so rewarding.

#1â€Šâ€”â€ŠColdÂ Shower

The first challenge was taking cold showers. I knew it was going to be tough given the Winter season, but boy, it was terrifying!

The first few days showering was the most dreaded part of my routine. But what started off as a one time challenge still continues to be the first thing that gets my day going.

#2â€Šâ€”â€ŠLearningÂ Spanish

After completing (28/30) the cold shower challenge, I tried out my luck with Spanish. I had always wanted to learn Spanish but never really got to studying it with dedication or discipline.

So I scavenged the Internet for some audio lessons, joined a language exchange group and spent 1 hour daily to explore the intricacies of the most romantic language.

By the end of the month, I could comfortably talk with my new Spanish native friends about everyday stuff.

#3â€Šâ€”â€ŠReading BeforeÂ Bed

Next up my to-do list was to dust off the books from my shelf and finally get around to reading them.

I decided to read everyday for about 30 minutes until I dozed off. This way I could avoid clinging on to my smartphone which usually turned my lets check out my facebook feed to me exploring theories on possible life on exoplanets.

# Takeaway

Sometimes it is better to start off, then plan.

You get the point, donâ€™t you?

Thanks for reading this.
